books.name: Naked Money, Charles Wheelan
Simulacron-3 by Daniel F. Galouye
The Old Man and the Sea by Ernest Hemingway
What Does It All Mean? A Very Short Introduction to Philosophy, Thomas Nagel
Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe, Benjamin Alire SÃ¡enz
The Tell Tale Brain, V. S. Ramachandran
What Does It All Mean by Thomas Nagel
books.review: This is the first book I've read in philosophy, and there will be many, many more for sure. This is a quick 100 page simple introduction of the questions philosophy asks - things I've been thinking about all my life. I liked the content and the ideas, many of which I have thought about before, but the way it was written didn't make it a fun read. Long, non-concise, overly-questiony sentences

books.name: The Making of Prince of Persia, Jordan Mechner
books.review: 25 year old developer who goes through the everyday struggles of life while maintaining a diary. I haven't ever connected to an author as much as I connected with Jordan. He has exactly the same mid 20s questions, the same career-life-relationships worries, the what ifs, and the where am I going, whilst also knowing that he's really doing a fairly good job at life.

books.name: When Google Met Wikileaks, Julian Assange
books.review: I wanted to read this book to know what hides behind Google's bright colorful logo, and this was good insight into it. I don't think it is a good idea commenting on this further though.

books.name: The Sun Is Also A Star
books.review: This was the first love story I've ever read, and I loved it. It's a book about perspectives, and what I loved was how the same scene plays differently in two people's heads. This book has a counterpart movie, and it was the first time I've read the book before watching the movie, and I have to say, the movie was awful. It lost everything that made the book special.

books.name: Ready Player One, Ernest Cline
books.review: Favorite book of all time. It's the first 500+ page book I've ever read non stop for 12 hours straight. I couldn't put it down! What makes it interesting is, Ready Player One is also a movie (Steven Spielberg!) and this is also the first time I consumed the same content in different formats.

books.name: Miss peregrine's home for peculiar children, Ransom Riggs
books.review: I read this is an audiobook. It took me all weekend to get throguh the 9 hours, but this was the first time I sat through an audiobook.

books.name: How to Win Friends and Influence People, Dale Carnegie
books.review: This was an okay read. I was brought up with all the insights the books provides as everyday discussions by my mother and father, and reading this just further strengthened them. It is a book that needs a re-read every now and then to remind you that the world is a fairly selfish place, and everyone is optimizing for themselves.

books.name: Nineteen Eighty-Four, George Orwell
books.review: Great book. A really, really great book! I completely understand Reddit's hype around this book.

books.name: Models, Mark Manson
books.review: Really, I have no shame in saying I read this - it's a book about picking up girls. The advice in the book is not bad per se - it advocates working on yourself, your body, your wardrobe, your knowledge. But the idea of *getting* girls was still a major part of the book that really made me realize how cheap that sounds. I've never had such relationships before. They've always been built on months of getting to know each other and that's what I value.

books.name: Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy, Douglas Adams
books.review: The entire book, all I kept thinking was 'What amazing wit!'. I wish to be able to write and speak in the voice of Douglas Adams some day. His writing is witty and hilarious, but also a very, very simple read.

books.name: Einstein's Dreams, Alan Lightman
books.review: A brilliant dramatic, almost romantic take on the various forms of time. It makes you think of how different the world would be if we perceived time differently. This book isn't for everyone. Everyone I've recommended this book to has disliked it, or found it hard to read.

books.name: Siddhartha, Herman Hesse
Atomic Habits, James Clear
Deep Work, Cal Newport
